Some children change their writing as they read aloud (ad-libbing improvements) rather than reading what is actually written on the page.

concepts.description: Pupils extend sentences with more than one clause using a wider range of conjunctions including when, if, because, although, creating subordinate clauses
concepts.teaching_guidance: Teach children to write multi-clause sentences using co-ordinating conjunctions (and, but, or, so) and subordinating conjunctions (when, if, because, that, although, while, after, before, until). Model combining short sentences into multi-clause sentences during shared writing. Teach children to vary their sentence structure — not every sentence needs to be multi-clause. Practise converting simple sentences into compound or complex sentences and vice versa. Use sentence-combining activities with sets of short sentences.
concepts.key_vocabulary: clause, multi-clause, conjunction, and, but, because, when, if, although, join, combine, sentence
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may overuse multi-clause sentences, creating sprawling constructions that lose clarity. They may default to one conjunction (usually 'and' or 'because') without varying their repertoire. Some children write multi-clause sentences without proper punctuation, particularly missing commas after fronted subordinate clauses.

concepts.description: Pupils understand and use the present perfect form of verbs (have/has + past participle) in contrast to the simple past tense, understanding the difference in meaning
concepts.teaching_guidance: Teach the present perfect tense as a way of expressing something that started in the past and continues to the present, or something completed at an unspecified time in the past. Contrast with the simple past: 'He went to town' (simple past — finished action) vs 'He has gone to town' (present perfect — he is still there). Use the formula: has/have + past participle. Practise converting between simple past and present perfect. Address irregular past participles (gone, seen, taken, written) alongside regular ones (walked, played).
concepts.key_vocabulary: present perfect, has, have, past participle, tense, simple past, -ed, gone, seen, taken, done
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children commonly use the simple past where the present perfect is needed (e.g., 'I already did it' instead of 'I have already done it'). They may confuse the present perfect with the simple past because both refer to past events. Some children use 'has went' or 'have went' instead of 'has gone' or 'have gone', reflecting non-standard dialect influence.

concepts.description: Pupils choose nouns or pronouns appropriately for clarity and cohesion, avoiding repetition and ensuring pronoun references are clear
concepts.teaching_guidance: Teach that pronouns replace nouns to avoid repetition and create cohesion in writing. Model the problem of not using pronouns: 'Sarah went to the shop. Sarah bought some bread. Sarah walked home.' Then show how pronouns improve the text: 'Sarah went to the shop. She bought some bread. She walked home.' Teach children to choose pronouns carefully so the reader always knows who or what is being referred to. Introduce possessive pronouns (his, her, their, its) alongside personal pronouns.
concepts.key_vocabulary: pronoun, he, she, it, they, him, her, them, replace, noun, cohesion, reference, who, clear
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children often use pronouns ambiguously, making it unclear which noun the pronoun refers to (e.g., 'Tom and Jack went out. He fell over.' — who fell?). They may over-use names instead of pronouns, creating repetitive writing. Some children use the wrong pronoun form ('him went' instead of 'he went').

concepts.concept_name: Conjunctions, adverbs and prepositions for time and cause
concepts.description: Pupils use conjunctions (when, before, after, while, so, because), adverbs (then, next, soon, therefore) and prepositions (before, after, during, in, because of) to express time, place and cause
concepts.teaching_guidance: Teach conjunctions (when, before, after, while, because, so), adverbs (then, next, soon, therefore) and prepositions (before, after, during, in, because of) as tools for expressing time, cause and effect. Show how these words link events and ideas: 'The road was icy. She slipped.' → 'Because the road was icy, she slipped.' / 'She slipped because the road was icy.' Practise using different connectives to express the same relationship. Create a classroom display of time and cause connectives for reference during writing.
concepts.key_vocabulary: conjunction, adverb, preposition, time, cause, because, when, before, after, while, then, so
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may use 'because' as their only causal connective, not varying their language. They may confuse temporal and causal connectives (e.g., using 'when' where 'because' is needed). Some children start sentences with connectives but do not complete the grammatical structure (e.g., 'Because the rain.' as a complete sentence).

concepts.description: Pupils place adverbials at the start of sentences for effect (e.g. Later that day, I heard the bad news.) and use commas after fronted adverbials
concepts.teaching_guidance: Introduce fronted adverbials in Year 3 as a sentence-opening device that adds variety and detail. Teach that a fronted adverbial is a word or phrase at the start of a sentence that tells the reader when, where or how something happened, followed by a comma: 'Slowly, the door creaked open.' 'After lunch, we went outside.' 'In the dark forest, a wolf waited.' Model adding fronted adverbials to plain sentences in shared writing. Practise through sentence-level activities before applying in extended writing.
concepts.key_vocabulary: fronted adverbial, adverbial, comma, sentence opener, when, where, how, time, place, manner
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may forget the comma after a fronted adverbial. They may overuse fronted adverbials, starting every sentence with one, which becomes repetitive. Some children confuse fronted adverbials with conjunctions and create sentence fragments. Others use only time adverbials ('First,... Then,... Next,...') rather than varying with place and manner.

concepts.description: Pupils use and punctuate direct speech correctly, beginning with introduction to inverted commas (speech marks) and basic speech punctuation conventions
concepts.teaching_guidance: Teach direct speech punctuation using the conventions: inverted commas (speech marks) around the spoken words, a new speaker on a new line, a comma or other punctuation before the closing speech mark, and a reporting clause (he said, she asked). Model with examples from class texts. Begin with simple reporting structures ('Hello,' said Tom.) before introducing variations (Tom said, 'Hello.' / 'Hello,' said Tom, 'how are you?'). Use drama to generate dialogue that children then write up with correct punctuation.
concepts.key_vocabulary: speech marks, inverted commas, dialogue, said, asked, replied, reporting clause, spoken words, new line
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children often forget to open or close speech marks, particularly when a sentence of dialogue is long. They may not place the comma before the closing speech mark. Some children do not start a new line for each new speaker, making dialogue difficult to follow. Others punctuate reported speech as if it were direct speech.

concepts.description: Pupils understand how prefixes create new nouns, particularly super- (supermarket, superstar), anti- (antiseptic, antisocial) and auto- (autobiography, autograph)
concepts.teaching_guidance: Teach how prefixes can be used to create nouns from other word classes: super- (superhero), anti- (antiseptic), auto- (autobiography). Demonstrate the pattern: identify the root word, add the prefix, note how the meaning changes. Connect to vocabulary development by exploring how these prefixes create words with specific meanings. Use word-building activities where children combine prefixes with root words to create and define new nouns. Link to reading comprehension — understanding these prefixes helps children decode unfamiliar vocabulary.
concepts.key_vocabulary: prefix, noun, word formation, super-, anti-, auto-, meaning, root word, create, derive
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may not realise that the prefix changes the meaning systematically (e.g., 'anti-' always means 'against'). They may confuse word-class changes from prefixes with those from suffixes. Some children add prefixes to words where they do not apply, creating non-existent words.

concepts.description: Pupils correctly choose between the articles 'a' and 'an' according to whether the next word begins with a consonant or vowel sound
concepts.teaching_guidance: Teach the rule for choosing between the indefinite articles 'a' and 'an': use 'a' before a consonant sound and 'an' before a vowel sound. Emphasise that the rule is about sound, not spelling: 'an hour' (silent h), 'a uniform' (y sound), 'an umbrella' (vowel sound). Provide practice exercises where children choose the correct article for given words. Connect to speaking — most children already use 'a' and 'an' correctly in speech and can transfer this knowledge to writing by saying the phrase aloud.
concepts.key_vocabulary: article, a, an, consonant sound, vowel sound, before, indefinite article, choose, rule
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may apply the rule based on the letter rather than the sound, writing 'an uniform' or 'a hour'. They may not realise that words beginning with 'h' can take either article depending on pronunciation. Some children omit articles entirely, particularly children whose home language does not use articles.

concepts.description: Pupils understand word families based on common words, showing how words are related in form and meaning (e.g. solve, solution, solver, dissolve, insoluble)
concepts.teaching_guidance: Teach word families as groups of words that share a common root word (e.g., solve, solution, dissolve, resolver, insoluble). Show how the root carries a consistent meaning across all words in the family. Use word family trees or webs as visual displays. When encountering unfamiliar words in reading, prompt children to identify whether the word belongs to a family they already know. Connect word families to spelling — knowing one word in a family often helps spell others.
concepts.key_vocabulary: word family, root word, related, connect, group, derive, base, same root, meaning, pattern
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may group words that look similar but are not actually related (e.g., 'play' and 'player' are related, but 'play' and 'place' are not). They may confuse word families with rhyming families. Some children understand word families in isolation but do not apply this knowledge as a reading or spelling strategy.

concepts.description: Pupils understand paragraphs as a way to group related material, introduced as an organisational concept in Year 3
concepts.teaching_guidance: Teach paragraphing as an organisational tool for grouping related material. In non-fiction, model how each paragraph focuses on one aspect of the topic, with a topic sentence that introduces the main idea. In fiction, teach the TIPTOP rule for starting new paragraphs: Time change, Introduce a new character, Place change, Topic change, Opposite (change of focus). Provide texts for children to divide into paragraphs, discussing the reasons for each break. Model paragraph structure explicitly during shared writing.
concepts.key_vocabulary: paragraph, topic, group, related, organise, main idea, topic sentence, new paragraph, TIPTOP, indent
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may understand that paragraphs exist but not know when to start a new one. They may create very uneven paragraphs — one or two very long paragraphs and several very short ones. Some children insert paragraph breaks mechanically (e.g., every five sentences) rather than according to content.

concepts.description: Pupils understand and use headings and sub-headings to aid presentation and organise information texts
concepts.teaching_guidance: Teach headings and subheadings as organisational tools that help readers navigate non-fiction texts. Model how to write clear, informative headings that tell the reader what a section is about. Analyse model texts: cover up the headings and ask children to predict what each section will contain based on the heading. In shared writing, compose texts where children suggest appropriate headings and subheadings. Teach the difference between headings (main topics) and subheadings (subtopics within a section).
concepts.key_vocabulary: heading, subheading, title, section, topic, organise, navigation, reader, information, non-fiction
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may write vague or unhelpful headings (e.g., 'Stuff' or 'Part 2' instead of 'How Volcanoes Erupt'). They may not understand the hierarchical relationship between headings and subheadings. Some children add headings after writing rather than using them to plan and organise content.

concepts.description: Pupils learn and use Year 3 grammatical terminology accurately: preposition, conjunction, word family, prefix, clause, subordinate clause, direct speech, consonant, consonant letter, vowel, vowel letter, inverted commas
concepts.teaching_guidance: Teach the Year 3 grammatical terminology from Appendix 2: preposition, conjunction, word family, prefix, clause, subordinate clause, direct speech, consonant, consonant letter, vowel, vowel letter, inverted commas (speech marks). Teach each term in context, using it when discussing reading and writing. Display definitions with examples. Practise identifying these features in texts. Test understanding through activities like 'find the preposition in this sentence' or 'underline the subordinate clause'.
concepts.key_vocabulary: preposition, conjunction, word family, prefix, clause, subordinate clause, direct speech, inverted commas
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may learn the definitions of grammatical terms without being able to identify examples in context. They may confuse prepositions with conjunctions when both can express similar meanings (e.g., 'before the match' vs 'before the match started'). Some children know the terms but cannot explain their function in a sentence.

concepts.description: Pupils begin to understand differences between Standard English and non-Standard English and start to apply Standard English in writing, for example in dialogue
concepts.teaching_guidance: Continue developing awareness of Standard English, focusing on subject-verb agreement and common non-standard forms. Address the specific verb forms that differ in many dialects: 'we were' not 'we was'; 'I did' not 'I done'; 'she saw' not 'she seen'; 'they went' not 'they gone'. Approach sensitively, validating dialect as appropriate in informal spoken contexts while teaching that Standard English is expected in writing and formal speech. Use editing activities where children identify and correct non-standard verb forms in written text.
concepts.key_vocabulary: Standard English, grammar, verb, correct form, formal, writing, we were, I did, she saw, agreement
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may feel that their dialect is being criticised when Standard English is taught, requiring a sensitive approach that values linguistic diversity. They may apply Standard English forms inconsistently, particularly in verbs that are common in non-standard dialect (e.g., 'done' for 'did'). Some children can identify non-standard forms in others' writing but not in their own.

prerequisite_relationships.rationale: KS1 listening skills develop into more sophisticated active listening and appropriate response in Year 3
KS1 questioning skills develop into Year 3 questioning to extend understanding and knowledge
KS1 vocabulary building develops into Year 3 use of relevant strategies to build vocabulary
KS1 speaking in full sentences to communicate ideas develops into Year 3 articulating and justifying answers and opinions
KS1 describing events and narratives develops into Year 3 well-structured descriptions, explanations and narratives
KS1 participation in collaborative conversation develops into Year 3 more sustained collaborative discussion
KS1 using talk to develop understanding develops into Year 3 exploratory talk including speculating and hypothesising
KS1 speaking clearly and fluently develops into Year 3 audible and fluent speech with increasing Standard English
KS1 participation in performances and drama develops into Year 3 wider range including debates and formal presentations
KS1 awareness of audience develops into Year 3 actively gaining, maintaining and monitoring listener interest
KS1 listening to others and responding develops into Year 3 evaluating different viewpoints and building on contributions
KS1 basic awareness of different contexts develops into Year 3 selecting appropriate registers for effective communication
KS1 knowledge of grapheme-phoneme correspondences and simple word structure is foundational to Year 3 applying root word knowledge for reading
KS1 introduction to prefixes and suffixes (un-, -ful, -less, -ness, -er) develops into Year 3 wider range of prefixes and suffixes with etymology
KS1 exception words develop into Year 3 further exception words from the Years 3-4 word list
Phonics knowledge from KS1 enables Year 3 pupils to try different pronunciations of longer unfamiliar words
KS1 listening to and discussing texts develops into Year 3 wider positive attitudes to reading across a broader range of text types
KS1 reading for different purposes develops into Year 3 reading books structured in different ways for a range of purposes
KS1 introduction to dictionaries develops into Year 3 systematic dictionary use for checking meaning
KS1 familiarity with stories and traditional tales develops into Year 3 specific study of fairy stories, myths and legends
KS1 beginning to identify features of different texts develops into Year 3 identifying themes and conventions across a wide range of books
KS1 reading aloud poems and play scripts develops into Year 3 performance with understanding through intonation, tone, volume and action
KS1 discussing language in texts develops into Year 3 identifying words and phrases that capture the reader's interest
KS1 exposure to various poems develops into Year 3 recognising and naming different forms of poetry
KS1 checking text makes sense and re-reading develops into Year 3 systematic comprehension monitoring and explaining word meaning in context
KS1 asking and answering questions about texts develops into Year 3 formulating questions to improve understanding
KS1 making simple inferences develops into Year 3 drawing inferences with evidence about feelings, thoughts and motives
KS1 making predictions develops into Year 3 predicting from both stated and implied details
KS1 identifying key points develops into Year 3 identifying main ideas across multiple paragraphs and summarising
KS1 awareness of how texts are organised develops into Year 3 identifying how language, structure and presentation contribute to meaning
KS1 finding information from non-fiction develops into Year 3 systematic retrieval and recording of information using contents and index
KS1 participating in discussion about books develops into Year 3 more structured discussion with rules for effective dialogue
KS1 beginning to read silently develops into Year 3 sustained silent reading with good understanding
KS1 basic prefix and suffix knowledge (un-, -ful, -less, -ness, -er, -est) is prerequisite for Year 3 wider range of prefixes and suffixes with rules
KS1 phonics knowledge and syllable awareness underpin Year 3 rules for doubling consonants in polysyllabic words
KS1 introduction to homophones (there/their/they're, here/hear, quite/quiet) develops into Year 3 wider set of homophones
KS1 phonics knowledge provides foundation for recognising etymology-based spelling patterns in Year 3
KS1 statutory word list (Years 1-2) is prerequisite for learning the new Years 3-4 statutory word list
KS1 use of apostrophe for singular possession develops into Year 3 possessive apostrophe with plural nouns
KS1 introduction to dictionaries develops into Year 3 systematic dictionary use for spelling checking
KS1 writing dictated sentences with taught words develops into Year 3 more complex dictated sentences
KS1 formation of individual letters and beginning to join develops into Year 3 use of diagonal and horizontal joining strokes
KS1 consistent letter sizing and spacing develops into Year 3 increased legibility, consistency and quality with attention to ascenders and descenders
KS1 discussing texts before writing and identifying features develops into Year 3 systematic analysis of model texts for structure, vocabulary and grammar
KS1 planning and writing sentences before writing develops into Year 3 systematic planning including discussing and recording ideas
KS1 composing sentences orally before writing develops into Year 3 rehearsing more complex sentences including dialogue
KS1 organising writing with a beginning, middle and end provides the foundation for Year 3 introduction to paragraphing
KS1 writing simple narratives with characters and events develops into Year 3 creating settings, characters and plot
KS1 sequencing and simple non-fiction writing develops into Year 3 using headings and sub-headings as organisational devices
KS1 re-reading to check writing makes sense develops into Year 3 systematic evaluation of effectiveness in own and others' writing
KS1 basic editing and correcting develops into Year 3 proposing specific grammar and vocabulary changes for consistency
KS1 re-reading to check spelling and punctuation develops into Year 3 systematic proof-reading
KS1 reading own writing aloud develops into Year 3 reading aloud to a group or class with appropriate intonation and volume
KS1 use of coordinating conjunctions (and, but, or) and subordinating conjunctions (because, when, if, that) develops into Year 3 wider range of conjunctions for multi-clause sentences
KS1 past and present tense is the foundational prerequisite for understanding the present perfect tense in Year 3
KS1 use of personal pronouns (I, he, she, we, they) develops into Year 3 systematic choice of nouns or pronouns for clarity and cohesion
KS1 use of conjunctions, adverbs and prepositions develops into Year 3 applying these specifically to express time, place and cause
KS1 adverbials and sentence-level grammar provide the foundation for Year 3 introduction to fronted adverbials
KS1 demarcating sentences with punctuation develops into Year 3 introduction to direct speech punctuation with inverted commas
KS1 introduction to simple prefixes (un-) develops into Year 3 understanding how super-, anti-, auto- form nouns
KS1 basic noun and determiner knowledge develops into Year 3 correct use of a/an articles
KS1 introduction to prefixes, suffixes and root words develops into Year 3 systematic study of word families
KS1 organising writing into sections with a beginning, middle and end provides the foundation for Year 3 introduction to paragraphs
KS1 sequencing information in non-fiction develops into Year 3 use of headings and sub-headings

KS1 grammatical terminology (noun, verb, adjective, adverb, sentence, punctuation, plural, singular) develops into Year 3 new terminology including preposition, conjunction, clause, subordinate clause
KS1 beginning awareness of spoken vs written language provides the foundation for Year 3 understanding Standard English vs non-Standard English
